questions.text: Drugs decreasing bone resorption in osteoporosis are all except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Teriparatide

 

Option B.

 

DRUGS IN OSTEOPOROSIS

 

  • Teriparatide is a PTH analogue and is given subcutaneously on anterior abdominal wall or anterolateral aspect of thigh.
  • It acts on the bone and stimulates osteoblasts to increase bone formation.
  • It is associated with increased risk of Osteosarcoma.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Raloxifene: Raloxifene is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM). It works by binding to estrogen receptors in bone.

 

Option C. Strontium: Strontium ranelate is a medication that was used for osteoporosis. It was believed to have a dual effect, both promoting bone formation and inhibiting bone resorption.

 

Option D. Risedronate: Risedronate belongs to a class of drugs known as bisphosphonates. Bisphosphonates are potent inhibitors of bone resorption. They work by inhibiting osteoclast activity, reducing bone turnover, and increasing bone mineral density

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Drug that do not decrease bone resorption in osteoporosis is Teripartide.
  • Teriparatide is a PTH analogue and is given subcutaneously on anterior abdominal wall or anterolateral aspect of thigh.

choices.text: Paget's disease of bone

questions.text: A 67-year-old man on biochemical analysis found to have three-fold rise of level of serum alkaline phosphatase to that of upper limit of normal value during a routine checkup but serum calcium and phosphorous concentration and liver function test results are normal. He is asymptomatic. The probable cause is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Paget's disease of bone

 

Option B.

 

DIAGNOSIS OF PAGET’S DISEASE

 

  • Paget's disease can have asymptomatic presentation with high ALP, normal calcium and phosphate.
  • ALP levels are used to monitor paget’s disease as it is the marker for bone formation.

 

Explanations:

 

Option A. Multiple Myeloma. Multiple myeloma is a malignancy involving plasma cells. Multiple myeloma will have normal ALP.

 

Option C. Primary hyperthyroidism. Primary hyperparathyroidism is characterized by an overactive parathyroid gland, leading to increased levels of parathyroid hormone (PTH) and subsequent hypercalcemia. In this case, serum calcium levels are reported as normal, making primary hyperparathyroidism less likely.

 

Option D. Osteomalacia. Osteomalacia is a condition of softening of the bones due to a deficiency of vitamin D or problems with its metabolism. It can lead to an increase in alkaline phosphatase. However, serum calcium and phosphorous concentration in osteomalacia would typically be abnormal, with decreased levels of serum calcium and phosphate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Paget's disease can have high ALP levels, and normal calcium and phosphate.

questions.text:
True about Pectus excavatum: 

 

  1. More common in female
  2. In severe cases, mitral valve prolapse may occur
  3. May be present at birth
  4. Seen in Marfan syndrome
  5. Impairment of respiratory function
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 2, 3, 4, 5

 

Option D.

 

PECTUS EXCAVATUM

 

  • Depression of the anterior chest wall
  • Funnel chest
  • Body of sternum is curved inwards
  • Involves 3rd-7th ribs

 

 

  • Decreased chest expansion
  • Decreased total lung capacity
  • It may be appreciated in an infant at birth or may develop later during childhood.
  • Male: Female ratio = 5:1
  • On evaluation, an audible murmur can attribute to defective mitral valve prolapse or regurgitation. This can be seen in severe cases.
  • Associations:
    • Prematurity
    • Congenital heart disease
    • Fetal Alcohol Disease
    • Homocystinuria
    • Marfan syndrome
    • Poland syndrome
    • Noonan syndrome

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pectus Excavatum may be present at birth.
  • In severe cases, mitral valve prolapse may occur.
  • It can be seen in Marfan syndrome.
  • It causes impairment of respiratory functions i.e., there is decreased total lung capacity due to decreased chest expansion.
  • It is more common in males.

choices.text: All of the above

questions.text: Genu recurvatum is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Option D.

 

GENU RECURVATUM

 

Genu Recurvatum or hyperextension of knee is seen in:

 

  • Trauma
  • R.A
  • Rickets
  • Poliomyelitis
  • Charcots
  • Congenital (due to Intrauterine positioning) – self resolving

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Genu Recurvatum also known as hypertension of knee can be seen in rheumatoid arthritis, poliomyelitis and rickets.

choices.text: All are correct

questions.text:
A child is diagnosed with hypophosphatemic rickets. Choose the correct statement:

 

  1. Serum calcium levels are mostly normal
  2. Raised levels of alkaline phosphate seen
  3. Has XLD inheritance
  4. PTH is markedly raised
  5. Pigeon chest is one of the characteristic skeletal deformity
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 3, 5

 

Option C.

 

HYPOPHOSPHATEMIC RICKETS

 

  • It is a disorder of bone mineralization caused due to defects (inherited/acquired) in the renal handling of phosphorus.
  • X-linked hypophosphatemic rickets is the most common inheritable form of rickets. 
  • It has an X-linked dominant inheritance.
  • Phosphate deficiency is the primary defect that results most commonly from increased renal excretion of phosphate.
  • It is associated with normal or slightly elevated serum parathyroid hormone (PTH). 
  • Pigeon chest can also be seen in such patients.
  • Differences between calcipenic and phosphopenic rickets:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Child is diagnosed with hypophosphatemic rickets and in this case, serum calcium levels are mostly normal, alkaline phosphate levels are mildly elevated.
  • It has X-linked dominant inheritance.
  • Pegion chest is one of the characteristic skeletal deformity associated with hypophosphatemic rickets.
  • PTH is normal or minimally elevated.

choices.text: Colles fracture
Scaphoid fracture

questions.text: Wrist X-ray shows:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rickets

 

Option A.

 

RADIOGRAPHIC FINDINGS IN RICKETS

 

  • The characteristic feature of rickets are thickening and widening of growth plate (physis).
  • Indistinct and hazy metaphysis that is abnormally wide (splaying) with cupping or flaring (Brush-like appearance).
  • Bowing of diaphysis, with thinning of cortices.
  • Looser's zone in 20%.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Colles Fracture. Colles fracture is fracture of lower end of radius at its corticocancellous junction mostly occurring in post-menopausal osteoporotic elderly women; as a result of fall on outstretched hand, with wrist in extension. It is one of the most common fractures in elderly. Radiographically, the fracture appears extra-articular and usually proximal to the radioulnar joint. Dorsal angulation of the distal fracture fragment is present. If dorsal angulation is severe enough, a dinner fork deformity may be described. There is also shortening of the radius. An associated ulnar styloid fracture is present in up to 50% of cases.

 

 

Option C. Scaphoid fracture. The wrist bone below the base of the thumb is known as the scaphoid bone. A fracture of this bone can happen when a person falls onto outstretched hands. This type of fracture does not happen very often in young children because this bone is mostly cartilage. A lucent line across the waist of the scaphoid is the commonest site for fracture. However, displaced and non-displaced fractures of the proximal and distal pole may be seen.

 

 

Option D. Osteoporosis. Osteoporosis is reduction in bone mass (density) i.e. there is quantitative decrease of units of bone formation but each unit has qualitatively normal configuration. So, osteoporosis characteristically has normal calcium, phosphate and alkaline phoshatase levels. In tubular bones especially metacarpals, there will be thinning of the cortex. Cortical thickness of <25% of the whole thickness of the metacarpal signifies osteoporosis (normal is 25-33%).

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • This given wrist X- ray shows rickets.
  • The characteristic feature of rickets are thickening and widening of growth plate, indistinct and hazy metaphysis that is abnormally wide (splaying) with cupping or flaring (Brush-like appearance).

choices.text: Serum calcium levels are normal
Serum vitamin D levels are normal
Growth plate healing becomes normal
Serum ALP becomes normal

questions.text: A 2-year-old child with rickets is on calcium supplements and has a foot deformity. The child will be referred to a surgeon for the correction of the deformity when:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Growth plate healing becomes normal

 

Option C.

 

FOOT DEFORMITY IN RICKETS

 

  • Corrective osteotomy in rickets should only be done once radiological healing has taken place otherwise the osteotomy will not unite due to defective mineralization.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Serum calcium levels are normal. Serum calcium levels are important for bone health, but correcting a foot deformity for 2-year-olds with rickets has more to do with normalizing growth plate healing than serum calcium levels. 

 

Option B. Serum vitamin D levels are normal. While normalizing serum vitamin D is essential for the treatment of rickets, it does not directly address the healing of the growth plate. Correcting the foot deformity has more to do with restoring normal growth plate function.

 

Option D. Serum ALP becomes normal. ALP is an enzyme involved in the mineralization of bone. Elevated ALP levels are commonly seen in rickets due to an increase in bone turnover. However, ALP normalization alone may not be enough to determine the right time for surgical correction of your foot deformity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The appropriate timing for surgical intervention based on the normalization of growth plate healing rather than relying solely on normal serum calcium, vitamin D levels, or alkaline phosphatase levels.

choices.text: Vitamin C deficiency
Vitamin D deficiency
Vitamin E deficiency

questions.text: Osteomalacia is due to:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin D deficiency

 

Option B.

 

OSTEOMALACIA

 

  • Osteomalacia is primarily caused by a deficiency of vitamin D, which is essential for the absorption of calcium and phosphorus in the intestines.
  • Inadequate levels of vitamin D result in impaired mineralization of the bone matrix, leading to soft and weak bones.
  • This condition is more commonly seen in adults.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Vitamin C deficiency. Vitamin C deficiency leads to scurvy, a condition characterized by weakness, anemia, gum disease, and skin problems. It is not associated with osteomalacia.

 

Option C. Vitamin E deficiency. Vitamin E is an antioxidant that plays a role in protecting cells from damage. However, vitamin E deficiency is not associated with osteomalacia. Instead, vitamin E deficiency can lead to neurological symptoms and muscle weakness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Osteomalacia is caused due to deficiency of Vitamin D, which is essential for absorption of calcium and phosphorus in the intestine.
  • Inadequate levels of Vitamin D result in impaired mineralization of the bone matrix, leading of soft and weak bones.

choices.text: Bowing of legs

questions.text: In Rickets, all are seen except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bleeding

 

Option C.

 

RICKETS

 

A – Abdomen protuberant

 

B – Bowing of bones (on weight bearing)

 

C – Costochondral junction prominent - (Rosary), Craniotabes (open fontanelles)

 

D – Diaphragm pull – Harrison’s groove (lateral indentation of chest due to pull of diaphragm on ribs)/Double malleolus

 

E – Enamel defect of teeth and delayed dentition

 

F – Forward sternum – Pigeon chest (Pectus carinatum)

 

G – Growth plate – widening

 

H – Hypocalcemia causing Hyper PtH

 

I – Irritability

 

J – Joint deformities – Genu valgum/genu varum/coxa vara

 

K – Kyphosis

 

L – Loosers zones

 

M – Milestone delayed/Muscle weakness

 

R – Rickets

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Bowing of legs. Bowing of legs is a classic clinical feature of rickets. Rickets is a disorder primarily seen in children, and it results from a deficiency of vitamin D, calcium, or phosphate. The deficiency leads to impaired mineralization of the bone matrix, causing the bones to become soft and bendable.

 

Option B. Rachitic rosary. Rachitic rosary refers to the beading or enlargement of the costochondral junctions (where the ribs meet the cartilage), giving a beaded appearance along the chest wall. This is a characteristic feature of rickets and results from the expansion of the cartilage due to the softening of bones.

 

Option C. Craniotabes. Craniotabes refers to the softening of the skull bones, which is another common manifestation of rickets. The skull bones become thin and pliable, leading to palpable depressions on the surface. This is particularly noticeable in the occipital region.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Bleeding is not typically associated with rickets.
  • Rickets primarily affects bone development and mineralization due to nutritional deficiencies, and bleeding is not a direct consequence of this condition.
  • The clinical features of rickets are mainly related to bone deformities, weakness, and abnormalities in the growth plates.

questions.text: In Hypophosphatemic Rickets, mode of inheritance is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) X-linked dominant

 

Option C.

 

HYPOPHOSPHATEMIC RICKETS

 

  • X-linked dominant (commonest).
  • It is due to PHEX gene mutation, autosomal dominant and autosomal recessive – 3 varieties of hypophosphatemic Rickets (vitamin D resistant rickets).
  • In hypophosphatemic rickets, phosphate deficiency is the primary defect that results most commonly from increased renal excretion of phosphate.
  • It is associated with normal or slightly elevated serum parathyroid hormone (PTH). 
  • Increased incidence of skeletal deformities, no hypocalcemia, hypophosphatemia, phosphaturia are seen.
  • Vitamin D is normal and ALP is high.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Autosomal dominant. Autosomal dominant inheritance means that the gene responsible for the condition is located on one of the autosomal chromosomes (non-sex chromosomes), and a single copy of the mutated gene from either parent is sufficient to express the trait. Hypophosphatemic rickets is not typically inherited in an autosomal dominant manner.

 

Option B. Autosomal recessive. Autosomal recessive inheritance implies that two copies of the mutated gene, one from each parent, are necessary for the expression of the trait.

 

Option C. X-linked recessive. In X-linked recessive conditions, the gene causing the disorder is located on the X chromosome, and males are typically more affected than females. Females are carriers but may not show the full phenotype.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • X- linked dominant is the commonest mode of inheritance in Hypophosphatemic Rickets.
  • It is due to PHEX gene mutation, autosomal dominant and autosomal recessive – 3 varieties of hypophosphatemic Rickets (vitamin D resistant rickets).

questions.text: Looser zone is a feature of:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Osteomalacia

 

Option B.

 

LOOSER ZONE

 

  • The term Looser’s zones, is eponymous of insufficiency fractures.
  • They occur at both weight and non-weight bearing sites, and correspond to the location where blood vessels traverse bone. 
  • Also known as cortical infractions, Milkman lines or pseudofractures.
  • They are wide, transverse lucencies with sclerotic borders traversing partway through a bone, usually perpendicular to the involved cortex.
  • Given that these lesions are a type of insufficiency fracture, they are not themselves diagnostic of osteomalacia.
  • Osteomalacia is the strongly favoured diagnosis when these are bilaterally symmetric and in a classic location such as the axillary border of the scapula, rib, or posterior ulna.
  • Other frequently involved sites include the superior and inferior pubic ramus, and medial side of the femoral neck. 
  • Complete fractures may occur through these weakened sites.
  • Looser zones contain regions of demineralized osteoid, frequently with superimposed osteitis fibrosa cystica due to the presence of hyperparathyroidism. 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Osteoporosis. Osteoporosis is a condition characterized by weakened bones, leading to an increased risk of fractures. In osteoporosis, bone density is reduced, and the bone structure becomes porous and brittle. However, the term "looser zone" is not specifically associated with osteoporosis.

 

Option C. Metastasis. Metastasis refers to the spread of cancer cells from the primary tumor to other parts of the body. The term "looser zone" is not typically associated with metastasis.

 

Option D. Scurvy. Scurvy is a nutritional deficiency disorder caused by a lack of vitamin C. It leads to symptoms such as weakness, fatigue, and joint pain. The term "looser zone" is not directly related to scurvy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Osteomalacia is a condition where the bone mineralization is impaired, resulting in softening of the bones.
  • The term "looser zone" refers to radiolucent or translucent bands seen in X-rays of bones affected by osteomalacia.

choices.text: Decrease in osteoid volume
Decrease in osteoid surface
Increase in osteoid maturation time
Increase in mineral apposition rate

questions.text: Osteomalacia is associated with:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Increase in osteoid maturation time

 

Option C.

 

OSTEOMALACIA

 

  • Osteoid maturation time refers to the duration it takes for the unmineralized bone matrix to undergo the process of mineralization.
  • In osteomalacia, there may be an increase in the time it takes for the osteoid to mature and become properly mineralized.
  • This prolonged maturation time is indicative of the impaired mineralization seen in osteomalacia.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Decreases in osteoid volume. Osteoid is the unmineralized, organic matrix of bone. In osteomalacia, there is a reduction in mineralization of the osteoid, leading to a decrease in bone density. This decrease in osteoid volume contributes to the characteristic softening of the bones seen in osteomalacia.

 

Option B. Decrease in osteoid surface. Osteoid surface refers to the area of unmineralized bone matrix available for mineralization. In osteomalacia, there is a decrease in the amount of osteoid being mineralized, which can result in a reduction in osteoid surface.

 

Option D. Increase in mineral apposition rate. Mineral apposition rate (MAR) is the rate at which mineral is deposited onto the bone matrix. In osteomalacia, there is typically a decrease in the mineral apposition rate, leading to inadequate mineralization of the bone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Osteomalacia is associated with increase in osteoid maturation time.
  • There may be an increase in the time it takes for the osteoid to mature and become properly mineralized.

choices.text: Wide open fontanelles

questions.text: Rickets in infancy is characterized by the following except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bow legs

 

Option D.

 

RICKETS IN INFANCY

 

  • Long bones of legs get deformed when the child starts bearing weight.
  • Therefore, deformities of legs are unusual before the age of one year.

 

A – Abdomen protuberant

 

B – Bowing of bones (on weight bearing)

 

C – Costochondral junction prominent - (Rosary), Craniotabes (open fontanelles)

 

D – Diaphragm pull – Harrison’s groove (lateral indentation of chest due to pull of diaphragm on ribs)/Double malleolus

 

E – Enamel defect of teeth and delayed dentition

 

F – Forward sternum – Pigeon chest (Pectus carinatum)

 

G – Growth plate – widening

 

H – Hypocalcemia causing Hyper PtH

 

I – Irritability

 

J – Joint deformities – Genu valgum/genu varum/coxa vara

 

K – Kyphosis

 

L – Loosers zones

 

M – Milestone delayed/Muscle weakness

 

R – Rickets

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Craniotabes. Craniotabes refers to the softening of the skull bones. In infants with rickets, the bones of the skull may become softened, leading to palpable depressions or "soft spots" on the skull. This can be a manifestation of the impact of vitamin D deficiency on bone mineralization.

 

Option B. Rachitic Rosary. Rachitic rosary is a term used to describe the beading at the costochondral junctions (the points where the ribs attach to the cartilage). In rickets, the deficient mineralization of the cartilage at these junctions can result in nodular swellings, giving the appearance of beads along the ribcage.

 

Option C. Wide open frontanelles. Fontanelles are soft spots on a baby's skull that allow for the growth of the skull bones. This can be associated with rickets in infancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In rickets, long bones of legs get deformed when the child starts bearing weight. Therefore, deformities of legs are unusual before the age of one year.

choices.text: Decreased osteoblastic activity
Defective osteoclastic resorption of uncalcified osteoid and cartilage
Defective proliferation of physis

questions.text: Basic pathological defect in rickets is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Defective osteoclastic resorption of uncalcified osteoid and cartilage

 

Option C.

 

OSTEOID FORMATION IN RICKETS

 

  • Osteoid formation is normal in rickets.
  • With defective mineralization, however, osteoclastic resorption of the uncalcified osteoid does not take place.
  • Therefore, osteoid is laid down irregularly with widened osteoid seams and osteoid islets.
  • Osteoid is increased in thickness, volume and total surface area.
  • Bone tissue throughout skeleton is incompletely calcified and therefore, softened.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Decreased osteoblastic activity. Osteoblasts are cells responsible for bone formation. In rickets, the primary issue is not decreased osteoblastic activity. Instead, the deficiency of vitamin D or other factors impairs mineralization, leading to a decreased ability to form properly mineralized bone matrix.  

 

Option B. Non-functional osteoclast. Osteoclasts are responsible for breaking down and resorbing bone tissue, a process that is essential for normal bone remodelling. If osteoclasts were non-functional, it would lead to an accumulation of bone rather than the characteristic bone deformities seen in rickets.

 

Option D. Defective proliferation of physis. The physis, also known as the growth plate, is crucial for bone growth in children. However, the basic pathological defect in rickets is not related to a defective proliferation of the physis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Basic pathological defect in rickets is Defective osteoclastic resorption of uncalcified osteoid and cartilage.
  • Osteoid formation is normal in rickets.
  • With defective mineralization, however, osteoclastic resorption of the uncalcified osteoid does not take place.

choices.text: All are correct

questions.text:
Action of vitamin D is that it: 

 

  1. Stimulates bone marrow
  2. Increases calcium loss
  3. Stimulates absorption of calcium
  4. Stimulates osteoclasts
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Only 3 & 4

 

Option C.

 

ACTION OF VITAMIN D

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Stimulates bone marrow.  Vitamin D does not directly stimulate bone marrow. The primary role of vitamin D is related to calcium metabolism, bone health, and other physiological processes. It helps regulate calcium absorption in the intestines, calcium reabsorption in the kidneys, and maintains calcium and phosphate levels in the blood.

 

Option B. Vitamin D actually has the opposite effect on calcium. It promotes the absorption of calcium from the intestines, reabsorption of calcium in the kidneys, and overall helps to maintain adequate levels of calcium in the blood. Therefore, it does not increase calcium loss.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Action of vitamin D is it stimulates absorption of calcium and stimulation of osteoclasts.

questions.text: Salt pepper skull is a feature of:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Primary hyperparathyroidism

 

Option C.

 

SALT PEPPER SKULL

 

  • Salt and pepper skull refers to multiple tiny well-defined lucencies in the calvaria caused by resorption of trabecular bone in hyperparathyroidism.
  • There is a loss of definition between the inner and outer tables of the skull and a ground-glass appearance as well as spotty deossification.

 

 

  • Skull appearance in other conditions:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Paget’s disease. Paget's disease is a chronic bone disorder characterized by excessive and abnormal bone remodeling. It is characterized by cotton wool skull appearance.

 

 

Option B. Eosinophilic granuloma. Eosinophilic granuloma is a localized form of Langerhans cell histiocytosis, a disorder involving the proliferation of certain white blood cells. It is characterized by Geographical lesion (Bevelled margins) in the skull.

 

 

Option D. Multiple Myeloma. Multiple myeloma is a cancer of plasma cells in the bone marrow. The skull gives a punched out appearance in this condition.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Salt and pepper skull is a radiographic feature of primary hyperparathyroidism.

questions.text: Brown tumor is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hyperparathyroidism

 

Option A.

 

BROWN TUMOR

 

  • Brown tumors are not actual tumors but rather focal areas of bone resorption that can occur in the setting of hyperparathyroidism.
  • It represents a reparative cellular process, rather than a neoplastic process.
  • Histologically, brown tumors are identical to giant cell tumors (both are osteoclastomas), and therefore, this entity can easily be misdiagnosed. 
  • Brown tumors have a slightly greater frequency in primary than in secondary hyperparathyroidism (3% versus 2%).
  • However, secondary hyperparathyroidism is much more common than primary hyperparathyroidism, therefore most brown tumors that are seen are associated with secondary hyperparathyroidism.
  • Common sites of involvement include: 
  • Mandible
  • Clavicle
  • Ribs
  • Pelvis 
  • Plain radiograph shows well-defined, purely lytic lesions that provoke little reactive bone. The cortex may be thinned or expanded, but will not be penetrated.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Hypoparathyroidism. Hypoparathyroidism is characterized by low levels of parathyroid hormone (PTH), leading to decreased calcium levels in the blood. In hypoparathyroidism, the bone resorption is typically reduced, and brown tumors are not a feature of this condition.

 

Option C. Hypothyroidism. Hypoparathyroidism is not associated with the development of brown tumors. Brown tumors are more commonly linked to hyperparathyroidism.

 

Option D. Hyperthyroidism. Hyperparathyroidism is characterized by overactivity of the parathyroid glands, leading to increased production of parathyroid hormone (PTH).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Brown tumors are not actual tumors but rather focal areas of bone resorption that can occur in the setting of hyperparathyroidism.

choices.text: Vitamin D intoxication
Tumor lysis syndrome
All are correct

questions.text: Hyperphosphatemia is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All are correct

 

Option D.

 

HYPERPHOSPHATEMIA

 

↑PO43- Levels are associated with:

 

  1. Increased oral intake
  2. Vitamin D intoxication
  3. Renal failure
  4. Hypoparathyroidism
  5. Pseudohypoparathyroidism
  6. Tumor calcinosis
  7. Tumor Lysis Syndrome
  8. Rhabdomyolysis
  9. Acute hemolysis

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Vitamin D intoxication. Vitamin D intoxication can produce hyperphosphatemia as a result of excessive gastrointestinal absorption and increased renal reabsorption.

 

Option B. Renal failure. Renal failure, especially in the context of chronic kidney disease (CKD), is a well-known cause of hyperphosphatemia. In normal kidney function, phosphorus is excreted in the urine, but in renal failure, there is a decreased ability to eliminate phosphorus, leading to its accumulation in the blood.

 

Option C. Tumor Lysis syndrome. Tumor lysis syndrome is a medical emergency that can occur after the treatment of certain cancers, especially those with high cell turnover rates. The rapid breakdown of cancer cells releases intracellular contents into the bloodstream, including phosphorus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hyperphosphatemia is abnormally high serum phosphate levels—can result from increased phosphate intake, decreased phosphate excretion, or a disorder that shifts intracellular phosphate to extracellular space.
  • Hyperphosphatemia is seen in Vitamin D intoxication, renal failure and tumor lysis syndrome.

choices.text: All of the above

questions.text: Pseudofracture can be seen in the following conditions:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Option D.

 

PSEUDOFRACURE

 

  • Milkman's/Increment fractures also known as looser's zones or osteoid zones are pseudofracture, seen at the sites of mechanical stress or nutrient vessel entry (pulsation).
  • These represent as incomplete (insufficiency) stress fractures that have healed by callus consisting of osteoid tissue lacking calcium (i.e. unmineralized woven bone).

 

 

X-ray hip – pseudofracture

 

  • It is seen in:
    • Osteomalacia (most characteristic)
    • Renal osteodystrophy
    • Hyperparathyroidism
    • Neurofibromatosis
    • Paget's disease
    • Polyostotic fibrous dysplasia
    • Osteogenesis imperfecta
    • Hereditary Hypophosphatasia
  • Common Locations:
    • Femoral neck (most common)
    • Pubic rami
    • Axillary edge of scapula immediately below the glenoid
    • Scapula lateral and superior border
    • Ribs and clavicle

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Hereditary Hypophosphatasia. Hereditary hypophosphatasia is a genetic disorder characterized by low levels of alkaline phosphatase, leading to impaired bone mineralization. Pseudofractures can be observed in individuals with hypophosphatasia due to the inadequate mineralization of bone, which may result in the appearance of radiolucent lines on X-rays.

 

Option B. Paget’s Disease. Paget's disease of bone is a condition characterized by abnormal bone remodeling, leading to enlarged and deformed bones. Pseudofractures can be associated with Paget's disease, occurring at sites of increased bone turnover and altered bone architecture.

 

Option C. Fibrous dysplasia. Fibrous dysplasia is a bone disorder where normal bone is replaced by fibrous tissue. Pseudofractures can be seen in fibrous dysplasia due to the weakened bone structure and altered bone matrix.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Milkman's/Increment fractures also known as looser's zones or osteoid zones are pseudofracture, seen at the sites of mechanical stress or nutrient vessel entry (pulsation).
  • Pseudofractures can be seen in hereditary hypophosphatasia, paget’s disease and fibrous dysplasia.

questions.text: Looser’s zone are seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Osteomalacia

 

Option B.

 

LOOSERS ZONE

 

It is Characteristically Seen in:

 

  • Osteomalacia (most characteristic)
  • Renal osteodystrophy
  • Hyperparathyroidism
  • Neurofibromatosis
  • Paget's disease
  • Polyostotic fibrous dysplasia
  • Osteogenesis imperfecta
  • Hereditary Hypophosphatasia

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Osteoporosis. Looser zones are not typically associated with osteoporosis. Osteoporosis is characterized by a reduction in bone density and quality, leading to an increased risk of fractures.

 

Option C. Rickets. Rickets is a disorder primarily affecting children, characterized by impaired mineralization of growing bones.

 

Option D. Scurvy. Scurvy is a nutritional deficiency disorder caused by a lack of vitamin C. While scurvy can lead to various bone and connective tissue abnormalities, it is not typically associated with the formation of Looser zones on X-rays.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Milkman’s/increment fractures also known as looser’s zones or osteoid zones are pseudofractures, seen at the site of mechanical stress or nutrient vessel entry.
  • Looser’s zone can be seen commonly in osteomalacia.

questions.text: Looser’s zone/Pseudofractures are commonly seen in the following areas except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Radius

 

Option D.

 

PSEUDOFRACTURES

 

Common Locations:

 

  • Femoral neck (most common)
  • Pubic rami
  • Axillary edge of scapula immediately below the glenoid
  • Scapula lateral and superior border
  • Ribs and clavicle

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Scapula. Looser zones can be seen in the scapula. These radiolucent lines may appear in various bones as a result of conditions like osteomalacia or rickets.

 

Option B. Ribs. Looser zones are commonly seen in the ribs. The ribs, being part of the skeletal system, can show these pseudofractures in conditions associated with impaired bone mineralization.

 

Option C. Pelvis. Looser zones can be observed in the pelvis. The pelvic bones, like other weight-bearing bones, may exhibit pseudofractures in conditions such as osteomalacia or rickets.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The common locations for pseudofractures are Femoral Neck, Pubic Rami, Axillary edge of scapula immediately below the glenoid, Scapula lateral and superior border, Ribs and clavicle and Pelvis.
  • It is not seen in Radius.

choices.text: Pseudofracture in adults
Fracture of clavicle in children
Fracture first metacarpal

questions.text: Milkman’s fracture is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pseudofracture in adults

 

Option A.

 

MILKMAN’S FRACTURE

 

  • Milkman's/Increment fractures also known as looser's zones or osteoid zones are pseudofracture, seen at the sites of mechanical stress or nutrient vessel entry (pulsation).
  • These represent as incomplete (insufficiency) stress fractures that have healed by callus consisting of osteoid tissue lacking calcium (i.e. unmineralized woven bone).
  • It is Characteristically Seen in:
    • Osteomalacia (most characteristic)
    • Renal osteodystrophy
    • Hyperparathyroidism
    • Neurofibromatosis
    • Paget's disease
    • Polyostotic fibrous dysplasia
    • Osteogenesis imperfecta
    • Hereditary Hypophosphatasia

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Fractures of clavicle in children. Clavicle fractures are relatively common in children, often occurring due to falls or trauma. The clavicle is a bone that connects the shoulder to the chest, and fractures can happen at various points along its length.

 

Option C. Fracture Humerus. Fractures of the humerus, the long bone of the upper arm, can occur in various locations and patterns. These fractures can happen due to trauma, falls, or other injuries.

 

Option D. Fracture first metacarpal. A fracture of the first metacarpal, often referred to as a "Bennett's fracture" or "Rolando fracture," involves the base of the thumb. It is a specific type of fracture that can occur in the first metacarpal bone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Milkman’s fracture is the pseudofracture in adults.
  • These are incomplete stress fractures that have healed by callus consisting of osteoid tissue lacking calcium.

questions.text: “Rugger Jersey spine” is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Renal osteodystrophy

 

Option C.

 

RUGGER JERSEY SPINE

 

  • ‘Rugger Jersey vertebrae' appears like sandwiches, with osteosclerosis adjacent to the end plates but relative radiolucency in the middle of vertebrae.
  • It is seen in renal osteodystrophy and osteopetrosis.
  • In patients of renal osteodystrophy, Rugger Jersey appearance is due to hyperparathyroidism and osteosclerosis.

 

 

Rugger Jersey Spine in Renal Osteodystrophy

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Fluorosis. Fluorosis is a condition caused by excessive intake of fluoride, leading to changes in bone and teeth. However, the "Rugger Jersey spine" is not typically associated with fluorosis.

 

Option B. Achondroplasia. Achondroplasia is a genetic disorder that affects bone growth, resulting in dwarfism. The "Rugger Jersey spine" is not a characteristic finding in achondroplasia.

 

Option D. Marfan’s syndrome. Marfan's syndrome is a genetic disorder that affects the connective tissue, leading to various skeletal, cardiovascular, and ocular abnormalities. The "Rugger Jersey spine" is not typically associated with Marfan's syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • "Rugger Jersey spine" is a radiological description of the appearance of the spine, particularly the vertebral bodies, seen on imaging studies.
  • It is seen in renal osteodystrphy in which alternate bands of osteosclerosis and radiolucency can be seen.

questions.text: Rugger Jersey spine in Chronic Renal Failure is due to:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hyperparathyroidism

 

Option C.

 

RUGGER JERSEY SPINE

 

  • Renal Osteodystrophy: Bony changes are combination of Rickets + Hyperparathyroidism + Osteoporosis + Osteosclerosis.
  • Renal osteodystrophy is more common in CRF. It is driven by presence of secondary hyperparathyroidism.
  • Pathophysiology begins with damaged glomerulus's inability to excrete phosphorus.
  • Hyperphosphatemia shuts down the production of vit D thus causing decreased calcium absorption from small intestine.
  • Hypocalcemia triggers release of PTH which enables the demineralization of bone to increase serum calcium level.
  • Osteosclerosis when present, is most common at the base of the skull and in vertebra causing horizontal stripped Rugger Jersey appearance.
  • ‘Rugger Jersey vertebrae' appears like sandwiches, with osteosclerosis adjacent to the end plates but relative radiolucency in the middle of vertebrae.
  • In patients of renal osteodystrophy, Rugger Jersey appearance is due to hyperparathyroidism and osteosclerosis.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Osteomalacia. Osteomalacia is a condition characterized by softening of the bones due to impaired mineralization. It is not typically associated with the "Rugger Jersey spine" appearance.

 

Option B. Trauma. Trauma alone is not a common cause of the "Rugger Jersey spine" appearance. This radiological finding is more related to metabolic and mineral disorders affecting bone density.

 

Option D. Aluminium osteodystrophy. Aluminium osteodystrophy is a form of renal osteodystrophy associated with chronic kidney disease. Exposure to high levels of aluminum in patients with impaired kidney function can lead to bone abnormalities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The "Rugger Jersey spine" appearance seen in chronic renal failure (CRF) is primarily due to increased bone density, particularly in the vertebral end plates. It is due to hyperparathyroidism.

questions.text: Wimberger ring sign is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Scurvy

 

Option A.

 

WIMBERGER RING SIGN

 

  • In scurvy, the margins of the epiphysis appears relatively sclerotic.
  • This is termed as ringing of epiphyses or Wimberger’s sign (ring sign).
  • It refers to a circular calcification surrounding the osteoporotic epiphyseal center of ossification in scurvy, which may result from bleeding.

 

Note: It must not be confused with Wimberger sign, pathognomonic for congenital syphilis.

 

 

Scurvy (sclerosed margins of epiphysis)

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Syphilis. Syphilis is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the bacterium Treponema pallidum. In congenital syphilis, Wimberger corner sign is seen which refers to the localized bilateral metaphyseal destruction of the medial proximal tibia.

 

Option C. Paget’s disease. Paget's disease of bone is a chronic disorder characterized by abnormal bone remodeling. The Wimberger ring sign is not commonly associated with Paget's disease.

 

Option D. Hemophilia. Hemophilia is a genetic disorder that affects blood clotting, but it is not typically associated with the Wimberger ring sign.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Wimberger’s ring sign is a radiographic feature of scurvy.

choices.text: Defective osteoid formation
Normal collagen and bone matrix
X-ray shows normal evidence

questions.text: Vitamin C deficiency leads to:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Defective osteoid formation

 

Option B.

 

VITAMIN C DEFICIENCY

 

  • Pathology:
    • Vitamin C is necessary for hydroxylation of lysine and proline to hydroxylysine and hydroxyproline, two amino acids crucial for proper cross-linking of triple helix of collagen.
    • So, deficiency causes failure of collagen synthesis or primitive collagen formation, throughout the body, including in blood vessels, predisposing to hemorrhage.
    • In bones, zone of proliferation is affected primarily.
    • Hemorrhage is capillary in origin and occurs from gums, alimentary tract, subcutaneous tissue, and bone especially at the most actively growing metaphysis and beneath periosteum.
    • Hemorrhage and fractures are common, but attempts of repair is disordered.
    • The provisional zone of calcification is weak leading to epiphyseal separations.
    • Dysfunctional osteoblast (flat resembling fibroblast) causes failure of osteoid formation resulting in generalized osteoporosis.
    • Chondroblast and mineralization is unaffected leading to persistence of calcified cartilage approaching metaphysis seen radiologically as opaque white line at junction of physis and metaphysis (Frankel's line).
    • Osteoclasts are normal, thin and fragile trabeculae and cortices of bone are seen.
    • Dentin formation in teeth is abnormal due to defective collagen.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Defective mineralization. Vitamin C is essential for the synthesis of collagen, a key component of bones and connective tissues. Deficiency of vitamin C can impair collagen formation, which, in turn, may affect mineralization of the bone matrix. This can lead to impaired bone density and strength.

 

Option C. Normal collagen and bone matrix. Vitamin C is crucial for the synthesis of collagen, and collagen is a fundamental component of bone matrix. Therefore, a deficiency in vitamin C can indeed lead to abnormal collagen and bone matrix formation.

 

Option D. X-ray shows normal evidence. X-rays may reveal abnormalities associated with vitamin C deficiency, such as changes in bone density, characteristic findings in scurvy, or alterations in the growth plates. Therefore, X-ray evidence may not be normal in the presence of vitamin C deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Vitamin C deficiency primarily affects collagen synthesis, including the collagen found in bone matrix, leading to defective osteoid formation.
  • This can result in various skeletal abnormalities, such as impaired mineralization and weakened bone structure.

questions.text: A young patient presents with enlargement of costochondral junction and with the white line of Frankel at the metaphysis. The diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Scurvy

 

Option A.

 

SCURVY

 

  • It develops after 6-12 months of dietary deprivation thus, not seen in neonates.

  • Clinical Feature:

    • Earliest features are restlessness, fretfulness, irritability, loss of appetite and failure to thrive

    • Gums maybe spongy and bleeding.

    • Subperiosteal hemorrhage is a distinct sign occurring most commonly in distal femur and tibia and proximal humerus, causing excruciating tenderness pain near the large joints. The child lies still to minimize pain or minimally move the affected limb (pseudoparalysis) (Frog like posture is attained by child).

    • Hemorrhage in soft tissue, joint, kidney, gut and petechiae may be seen.

    • Anemia and impaired wound healing is seen.

    • Beading of ribs at costochondral junction (Scorbutic rosary).

    • Systemic reaction (fever) is absent initially.

 

Note: 

 

Enlargement of costochondral junction is seen in both rickets and scurvy.

 

  • In rickets, it is called "rachitic rosary" (Round and non-tender), due to overgrowth of cartilage.

  • In scurvy, it is called "scorbutic rosary" (Sharp and tender), due to bleeding and defective osteoid formation.

 

So this finding alone is not enough to distinguish between the two.

 

Radiological Feature:

 

 

Scurvy (sclerosed margins of epiphysis)

 

 

Scurvy

 

  • Osteopenia (ground glass appearance) (1st sign) with thinning of cortex (pencil thin cortex).

  • Metaphysis maybe deformed or fractured.

  • Frankel's line (zone of provisional calcification increases in width and opacity) due to failure of resorption of calcified cartilage and stands out compared to the severely osteopenic metaphysis. This is a classic radiological sign of scurvy, not rickets.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Rickets. Rickets is a condition primarily caused by a deficiency of vitamin D, calcium, or phosphate. It affects the mineralization of bones and can lead to deformities. In the growing skeleton, the deficiency of normal mineralization is most evident at metaphyseal zones of provisional calcification where there is an excess of non-mineralized osteoid resulting in growth plate widening and abnormal configuration of the metaphysis in the form of fraying (indistinct margins of the metaphysis), splaying (wide metaphyseal ends), cupping (concave metaphysis), and pseudofracture on the compression side of bone. They are most prominent at the bones where growth is greatest i.e., distal femur, proximal tibia, wrist especially the ulna, and anterior rib ends (rachitic rosary).

 

 

Option C. Hyperparathyroidism. Hyperparathyroidism involves an overactive parathyroid gland leading to excessive levels of parathyroid hormone (PTH). This can result in increased calcium reabsorption from bones, causing bone resorption. Radiographically, there is subperiosteal bone resorption seen in the 2nd and 3rd phalanges, tibia, femur and humerus; subchondral resorption in lateral end clavicle, pubic symphysis and SI joints; subligamentous resorption in ischial tuberosity, trochanters, calcaneus and clavicle, rugger jersey spine, osteopenia, brown tumors, salt-pepper skull are seen.

 

Option D. Osteomalacia. Osteomalacia is a condition characterized by softening of the bones due to inadequate mineralization. It is often caused by a deficiency of vitamin D, resulting in impaired calcium and phosphate metabolism. Radiogrphically, it shows osteporotic-like pattern of demineralization, blurred trabeculae, loosers zone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Enlargement of costochondral junction (rosary) and white line of Frankel is seen in scurvy.

  • Scurvy is caused by vitamin C deficiency

  • It affects collagen synthesis and leads to:

    • White line of Frankel

    • Trmmerfeld zone (lucent band below Frankel line)

    • Pelkan spurs

    • Wimbergers sign

    • Subperiosteal hemorrhages

  • White line of Frankel = Scurvy

  • Cupping/fraying/widened epiphysis = Rickets.

questions.text: A 75-year-female has chronic backache. X-ray spine is shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Osteoporosis

 

Option B.

 

OSTEOPOROSIS

 

  • Decreased bone density can be appreciated by decreased cortical thickness and loss of bony trabeculae in the early stages in radiography.
  • Vertebra, long bones like proximal femur, calcaneum and tubular bones are usually looked at for evidence of osteoporosis.
  • Nevertheless, DEXA is the gold standard of diagnosing osteoporosis.
  • Plain radiograph of the vertebral osteoporosis manifests as
    • Pencilling of vertebrae
    • Loss of cortical bone and trabecular bone (ghost vertebra)
    • Compression fractures and vertebra plana 
    • Prominent vertical (primary) trabeculae with thinning of horizontal/secondary trabeculae in vertebral bodies
  • The compression fracture of the vertebra gives the appearance of codfish vertebra.

 

 

  • There is loss of trabeculae in the proximal femur area and calcaneum.
  • In tubular bones especially metacarpals, there will be thinning of the cortex.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Pott’s spine. Pott's spine, or spinal tuberculosis, can cause chronic backache, particularly in the elderly. It may be associated with vertebral collapse and destruction seen on X-rays. Radiographic manifestations of tuberculous spondylitis include intraosseous and paraspinal abscess formation, subligamentous spread of infection, vertebral body destruction and collapse, and extension into the spinal epidural space.

 

 

Option C. Spondylolisthesis. Spondylolisthesis involves the displacement of one vertebra over another. It can result in chronic back pain, and X-rays may show the abnormal alignment of the vertebrae.

 

 

Option D. Spondylodiscitis. Spondylodiscitis refers to an infection of the intervertebral disc and adjacent vertebral bodies. It can cause chronic back pain, and X-rays may show disc space narrowing and vertebral destruction. MRI is the imaging modality of choice that shows faint bone marrow edema, paravertebral soft tissue change, acute Schmorl’s node, disc extrusion, malignancy, or acute endplate injury.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given image shows codfish vertebra, which is diagnostic of osteoporosis.
  • Codfish vertebrae are seen due to compression fracture of the spine.

choices.text: Vitamin D supplementation
Do MRI scan
Go for screw fixation of L1 vertebra
To take Dexamethasone

questions.text: A 70-year-old lady got compression fracture of L1 vertebra. There is no neurological deficit to this patient. What advise will you give for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin D supplementation

 

Option A.

 

COMPRESSION FRACTURE OF L1 VERTEBRA

 

  • Vertebral compression fractures are the most common fragility fracture.
  • It affects up to 25% people over 70 years
  • On physical examination, there is focal tenderness of spinous process, local kyphosis.
  • Signs of spinal cord compression are very rare
  • Nerve root deficits may be present with compression fractures of lumbar spine that lead to severe foraminal stenosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Do MRI scan. An MRI scan is not typically the first-line investigation for uncomplicated vertebral compression fractures. MRI is indicated in osteoporotic collapse in case of neural deficit.

 

Option C. Go for screw fixation of L1 Vertebra. Surgical intervention, such as screw fixation, is generally reserved for cases with severe instability, neurological deficits, or failure of conservative management. Decompression and fixation is done for unstable spine and compromised spinal canal.

 

Option D. To take dexamethasone. Dexamethasone, a corticosteroid, is not typically used as the first-line treatment for uncomplicated vertebral compression fractures. Steroids are given in spinal injuries to reduce edema associated with the trauma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Vitamin D is crucial for bone health and calcium absorption.
  • In the context of a compression fracture, ensuring adequate vitamin D levels is important for overall bone strength and healing.
  • Therefore, vitamin D supplementation may be recommended to support bone health.

questions.text: Which bisphosphonate is approved for the treatment of osteoporosis and is given on yearly basis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Zoledronate

 

Option B.

 

TREATMENT OF OSTEOPOROSIS

 

  • Zolendronate is a bisphosphonate which increases the risk of Acute Kidney injury.
  • It is given on yearly basis and the patient should be properly hydrated before its administration.
  • Bisphosphonates inhibit osteoclast to decrease the bone resorption.
  • They should be taken on an empty stomach with a glass full of water and the patient is advised not lay down for next 30 minutes of taking the drug.
  • Side effects: Pill-induced esophagitis, Osteonecrosis of Jaw, Atypical Femoral neck fractures.
  • Prolonged use of Bisphosphonates has been reported with increased incidence of fractures of proximal femur. Hence, a patient on Bisphosphonates with hip pain requires X-rays to evaluate and diagnose these fractures.

 

      

Explanation:

 

Option A. Alendronate. Alendronate is a bisphosphonate commonly used for the treatment of osteoporosis. However, the standard dosing regimen for alendronate is usually once weekly.

 

Option C. Risedronate. Risedronate is another bisphosphonate used for the treatment of osteoporosis. The standard dosing regimen for risedronate is often once weekly or once monthly.

 

Option D. Ibandronate. Ibandronate is available in both oral and intravenous forms. It is given in a monthly dose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Bisphosphonate which is approved for the treatment of osteoporosis and is given on yearly basis is Zolendronate.
  • It increases the risk of Acute Kidney Injury.
  • It is given on yearly basis and the patient should be properly hydrated before its administration.
  • Bisphosphonates inhibit osteoclast to decrease the bone resorption.

questions.text: All the following are used in osteoporosis except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Milnacipran

 

Option D.

 

  • This drug is used for fibromyalgia.
  • It is a class of medications called serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Denosumab. Denosumab is a medication used to treat osteoporosis by inhibiting bone resorption.

 

Option B. Strontium. Strontium ranelate is another option used for the treatment of osteoporosis.

 

Option C. PTH. Parathyroid hormone (PTH), specifically teriparatide, is also used in the management of osteoporosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Out of the given options, the drug which is not used in osteoporosis is Milnacipran. It is primarily used as an antidepressant and for the management of fibromyalgia.

choices.text: Normal calcium, decreased ALP
Decreased calcium, increased ALP
Normal calcium, normal ALP
Decreased calcium, decreased ALP

questions.text: In Osteoporosis, which of these is seen?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Normal calcium, normal ALP

 

Option C.

 

OSTEOPOROSIS

 

  • Calcium and phosphate are important components of bony inorganic matrix and major factors in maintenance of bone health.
  • Serum total ALP, osteocalcin, urinary calcium and hydroxyproline are strong predictors of bone loss.
  • Osteoporosis is reduction in bone mass (density) i.e. there is quantitative decrease of units of bone formation but each unit has qualitatively normal configuration.
  • So, osteoporosis characteristically has normal calcium, phosphate and alkaline phoshatase levels.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Normal calcium, decreased ALP. This combination is not typical for osteoporosis. In osteoporosis, calcium levels are usually normal or slightly decreased, and ALP levels are typically normal.

 

Option B. Decreased Calcium, increased ALP. This combination is not characteristic of osteoporosis. Osteoporosis itself is not associated with a significant decrease in calcium levels. Additionally, ALP levels are usually normal in osteoporosis.

 

Option D. Decreased Calcium, decreased ALP. This combination is not commonly seen in osteoporosis. While there may be a slight decrease in calcium levels in osteoporosis, the ALP levels typically remain normal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In osteoporosis, the typical laboratory findings are generally within the normal range or may show a slight decrease in calcium levels.
  • However, alkaline phosphatase (ALP) levels are usually normal.

choices.text: Age, race and sex matched individuals
Race and sex matched individuals

questions.text: Z-score measures the bone mineral density compared to:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Age, race and sex matched individuals

 

Option A.

 

Z SCORE

 

  • Z score compares the patients BMD with that of adult of the same race, age and sex.
  • Z Score indicates possible secondary osteoporosis.
  • A Z Score of -2 or below should trigger investigation for underlying disease.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Race and sex matched individuals. The Z score is more comprehensive than just comparing to race and sex. It includes age as well because bone mineral density can vary with age. Therefore, the Z score accounts for age, race, and sex.

 

Option C. Sex matched individuals. While sex is an important factor in bone density, the Z score goes beyond comparing only with individuals of the same sex. It also considers age and race to provide a more accurate assessment of bone mineral density.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Z score measures the bone mineral density is compared to age, race and sex matched individuals.
  • Z score compares the patients BMD with that of adult of the same race, age and sex. It indicates possible secondary osteoporosis.

questions.text: The bodies of spine are biconcave and are called “codfish spine”. This is most commonly seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Osteomalacia

 

Option B.

 

CODFISH SPINE

 

Codfish Vertebra is seen in:

 

  1. Osteoporosis > Osteomalacia
  2. Sickle cell disease
  3. Hereditary spherocytosis
  4. Homocystinuria
  5. Renal osteodystrophy
  6. Osteogenesis imperfecta
  7. Gaucher's disease

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Scurvy. Scurvy is a condition caused by vitamin C deficiency. In scurvy, the collagen synthesis is impaired, leading to weakened connective tissues. This can result in various musculoskeletal manifestations, including bone abnormalities. However, the classic biconcave appearance of the vertebral bodies, are not typically associated with scurvy. The spine is rarely affected in scurvy.

 

Option C. Fluorosis. Fluorosis is a condition caused by excessive fluoride intake, leading to skeletal and dental abnormalities. However, the classic biconcave appearance of the vertebral bodies, are not associated with fluorosis. Vertebral osteophytosis with soft-tissue calcification and ossification is common but non-specific feature of fluorosis. This sign can also be seen in diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis, ankylosing spondylitis, psoriasis, acromegaly, neuropathy.

 

Option D. Hyperparathyroidism. Hyperparathyroidism is a condition where there is an excess of parathyroid hormone, leading to increased calcium levels in the blood. Severe and prolonged hyperparathyroidism can cause bone resorption and deformities. It is not associated with the classic biconcave appearance of the vertebral bodies. The spine in this condition gives a ruggery jersey sign which is the osteosclerosis of the end plates and radiolucency of the middle of the vertebral body.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The biconcave appearance of vertebral bodies, known as "codfish spine," is most commonly associated with osteomalacia, which is caused by vitamin D deficiency and results in inadequate mineralization of the bone matrix.

choices.text: Single beam densitometry
Quantitative computed tomography

questions.text: Gold standard for diagnosis of osteoporosis:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) DEXA

 

Option A.

 

INVESTIGATIONS FOR OSTEOPOROSIS

 

  • Bone Mineral Density is measured by DEXA (Dual Emission X-ray Absorptiometry) Scan and it is matched to Dexa scan of 30-year-old individual and T score is calculated.
  • WHO classification:
    • T score 0 to –1 is normal
    • T score –1 to –2.5 is osteopenia
    • T score less than –2.5 is osteoporosis

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Single beam densitometry. Single Beam Densitometry is an older and less accurate method compared to DEXA. It measures bone density using a single X-ray beam, but it is not as precise as DEXA in assessing bone mineral density.

 

Option C. Quantitative computed tomography. QCT is another imaging technique that measures bone mineral density using computed tomography scans. While QCT provides detailed three-dimensional images of bone density, it is not as commonly used as DEXA for routine osteoporosis diagnosis.

 

Option D. Bone histomorphometry. Bone histomorphometry involves the microscopic examination of bone tissue obtained through a bone biopsy. It provides detailed information about bone structure and mineralization. However, bone histomorphometry is an invasive procedure and is not typically used as a routine diagnostic tool for osteoporosis. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • DEXA remains the gold standard for the diagnosis of osteoporosis in routine clinical practice due to its precision, non-invasiveness, and widespread availability.

questions.text: Most common site of osteoporosis:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vertebrae

 

Option B.

 

OSTEOPOROSIS

 

  • Osteoporosis is a bone disease that develops when bone mineral density and bone mass decreases.
  • This can lead to a decrease in bone strength that can increase the risk of fractures.
  • Osteoporosis is a “silent” disease because it typically do not have symptoms until a bone is broken.
  • Osteoporosis is the major cause of fractures in postmenopausal women and in older men.
  • Fractures can occur in any bone but happen most often in bones of the hip, vertebrae in the spine, and wrist.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Humerus. While osteoporosis can affect various bones in the body, fractures in the humerus (arm bone) are not as common as fractures in other areas such as the spine, hip, or wrist.

 

Option C. Scapula. The scapula (shoulder blade) is not a typical site for osteoporosis-related fractures. Osteoporotic fractures more commonly occur in weight-bearing bones such as the spine and hip.

 

Option D. Flat bone. Flat bones, such as the ribs and certain bones in the skull, are not as commonly affected by osteoporosis-related fractures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The vertebrae, particularly the thoracic and lumbar spine, are commonly affected by osteoporosis-related fractures.
  • These fractures can lead to a loss of height, spinal deformities and back pain.
  • Vertebral fractures are often associated with osteoporosis, especially in older individuals.

questions.text: Denosumab – a monoclonal antibody against RANKL receptor, is used in treatment of:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Osteoporosis

 

Option B.

 

RANKL INHIBITOR

 

  • RANKL (receptor activator of nuclear factor – KB ligand) a protein expressed by osteoblastic stromal cells, binds to RANK (receptor activator of nuclear factor KB) and is primary mediator of osteoclast differentiation, activation and survival.
  • So, RANKL is responsible for osteoclast-mediated bone resorption.
  • Osteoprotegerin, a soluble RANKL receptor, is a key regulator of RANKL-RANK pathway of osteoclastic resorption.
  • Denosumab is a fully human monoclonal antibody (Ig C2) that binds RANKL (mimicking osteoprotegerin) and blocks interaction of RANKL with RANK and it inhibits osteoclast function.
  • Estrogen suppress pathway through which RANKL and M-CSF (macrophage colony stimulating factor) induce monocyte precursors to develop into osteoclasts.

 

 

RANK-RANK-Ligand

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Rheumatoid arthritis. Denosumab is not typically used as a primary treatment for rheumatoid arthritis. Rheumatoid arthritis involves inflammation of the joints and is usually managed with disease-modifying anti-rheumatic drugs (DMARDs) like methotrexate, and biological agents targeting inflammatory pathways.

 

Option C. Osteoarthritis. Denosumab is not a primary treatment for osteoarthritis. Osteoarthritis is a degenerative joint disease, and its management involves pain relief, lifestyle modifications, and sometimes joint replacement surgery in severe cases.

 

Option D. SLE. Denosumab is not a standard treatment for systemic lupus erythematosus. SLE is an autoimmune disease, and its management typically involves immunosuppressive medications, corticosteroids, and other targeted therapies depending on the specific manifestations.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • Denosumab is approved for the treatment of osteoporosis in postmenopausal women and in men at increased risk of fractures.
  • It helps to increase bone density by inhibiting bone resorption, making it a valuable option for the management of osteoporosis.

choices.text: Compression fracture of the spine
Asymptomatic, detected incidentally by low serum calcium
Bowing of legs
Loss of weight

questions.text: The most common manifestation of osteoporosis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Compression fracture of the spine

 

Option A.

 

  • Remember, most common presentation is asymptomatic (Calcium is normal).
  • Early, detectable signs of bone loss are rare.
  • Often patients don’t know they have weak bones until there is a fracture of hip, wrist, or spine.
  • In case of fracture of the spine, there is compression of the vertebral body, found on a radiograph as codfish appearance, diagnosing osteoporosis.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Asymptomatic, detected incidentally by low serum calcium. Osteoporosis can be asymptomatic in its early stages, and individuals may not experience noticeable symptoms. It is not typically detected by low serum calcium levels. Instead, diagnosis is often based on bone mineral density (BMD) tests like dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry (DEXA) scans, which measure bone density and assess the risk of fractures. The serum calcium level is normal in cases of osteoporosis. 

 

Option C. Bowing of legs. Bowing of the legs is not a common manifestation of osteoporosis. Bowing of the legs is more commonly associated with conditions like rickets or osteomalacia, which involve a softening of the bones due to vitamin D deficiency.

 

Option D. Loss of weight. Weight loss is not a direct manifestation of osteoporosis. Instead, the patient or their family members may have noticed a gradual decrease in height of the patient by few cms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Osteoporosis often results in decreased bone density and strength.
  • This can lead to compression fractures in the vertebrae of the spine, especially in the thoracic and lumbar regions.

questions.text: Increased bone density with hyperostosis seen in skeletal fluorosis is likely to occur when fluorine concentration in drinking H2O is above:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 10 ppm

 

Option B.

 

FLORINE CONCENTRATION

 

  • In some parts of India and Africa, where fluorine concentration in the drinking water maybe above 10 ppm, chronic fluorine intoxication (fluorosis) is endemic and results in skeletal anomalies.
  • Fluorine stimulates osteoblastic activity; fluorapatite crystals are laid down in bone and these are usually resistant to osteoclastic resorption.
  • This leads to calcium retention and secondary hyperparathyroidism.
  • Characteristic pathological feature is subperiosteal new bone accretion and osteosclerosis (increased bone density) most marked in vertebrae, ribs, pelvis, forearm and leg bones, together with hyperostosis at the bony attachments of ligaments, tendons and fascia.
  • Despite the apparent thickening and density of skeleton, tensile strength is reduced and the bones fracture more easily.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. 6ppm. This is a lower concentration of fluoride in drinking water. At this level, the risk of skeletal fluorosis is relatively low, and hyperostosis (increased bone density) is less likely to occur.

 

Option C. 15ppm. With a fluoride concentration of 15 ppm, the risk of developing skeletal fluorosis, including hyperostosis, becomes more significant. Prolonged exposure to such high levels of fluoride in drinking water can lead to increased bone density and other skeletal abnormalities.

 

Option D. 20ppm. This is an even higher concentration of fluoride in drinking water.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In some parts of India and Africa, where fluorine concentration in the drinking water maybe above 10 ppm, chronic fluorine intoxication (fluorosis) is endemic and results in skeletal anomalies.

questions.text: Increased bone density occurs in:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fluorosis

 

Option C.

 

FLUOROSIS

 

  • Fluorine stimulates osteoblastic activity; fluorapatite crystals are laid down in bone and these are usually resistant to osteoclastic resorption. This leads to calcium retention and secondary hyperparathyroidism.
  • Characteristic pathological feature is subperiosteal new bone accretion and osteosclerosis (increased bone density), most marked in vertebrae, ribs, pelvis, forearm and leg bones, together with hyperostosis at the bony attachments of ligaments, tendons and fascia.
  • Despite the apparent thickening and density of skeleton, tensile strength is reduced and the bones fracture more easily.
  • First clinical manifestation is usually a stress fracture, back pain, bone pain, joint stiffness and neurological defects (due to hyperostosis encroaching on vertebral canal).
  • Characteristic X-ray features are osteosclerosis, osteophytosis and ossification of ligamentous and fascial attachments.
  • Radiologically can be mistaken for other osteosclerotic conditions such as Paget's disease, osteopetrosis, renal osteodystrophy, idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis, etc.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cushing syndrome. Cushing syndrome is a disorder characterized by prolonged exposure to high levels of cortisol, a hormone produced by the adrenal glands. There is abnormal bone turnover, decreased bone density, and increased risk of fracture due to excessive glucocorticoids. 

 

Option B. Hypoparathroidism. Hypoparathyroidism is a condition where the parathyroid glands produce insufficient parathyroid hormone (PTH), leading to low calcium levels in the blood. In hypoparathyroidism, bone density may be normal or slightly decreased, but it is not typically associated with increased bone density.

 

Option D. Hyperthyroidism. Hyperthyroidism is a condition where the thyroid gland produces an excess of thyroid hormones. Hyperthyroidism is associated with accelerated bone remodelling, reduced bone density, osteoporosis and increased fracture rate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Fluorosis is caused by excessive accumulation of fluoride, usually from sources like drinking water.
  • It is characterized by increased bone density and changes in bone structure.

choices.text: Sclerosis of sacroiliac joint
Interosseous membrane ossification
Osteosclerosis of vertebral body
Ossification of ligaments of knee joint

questions.text: What is the diagnostic radiological finding in skeletal fluorosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Interosseous membrane ossification

 

Option B.

 

RADIOGRAPHIC FINDINGS OF FLUOROSIS

 

  • Osteosclerosis, osteophytosis and ossification of ligamentous and fascial attachments is characteristic of fluorosis and amongst them most important is Interosseous membrane ossification.
  • Radiologically, it can be mistaken for other osteosclerotic conditions as Paget's disease, osteopetrosis, renal osteodystrophy, idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis, etc.

 

 

Ossification of interosseous membrane in fluorosis

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Sclerosis of sacroiliac joint. Sclerosis refers to abnormal hardening or thickening of tissues.

 

Option C. Osteosclerosis of vertebral body. Osteosclerosis in the vertebral bodies refers to the increased density or hardening of the bones in the spine.

 

Option D. Ossification of ligaments of knee joint. In skeletal fluorosis, there can be abnormal calcification and ossification of ligaments around joints, including the knee joint.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The diagnostic radiological finding in skeletal fluorosis is Interosseous membrane ossification.
  • Osteosclerosis, osteophytosis and ossification of ligamentous and fascial attachments is characteristic of fluorosis.

choices.text: Infantile cortical hyperostosis
Osteomyelitis of jaw in children
Chronic osteomyelitis in children

questions.text: Caffey’s disease is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Infantile cortical hyperostosis

 

Option B.

 

CAFFEY’S DISEASE

 

  • Caffey’s disease is also called as infantile cortical hyperostosis.
  • Infantile cortical hyperostosis (Caffey's disease) is a self-limiting disorder characterized by soft tissue swelling, rapid subperiosteal new bone formation, cortical thickening of underlying bones, fever and irritability.
  • Classically, the onset of disease occurs before 6th month of life with resolution by 3 years of age.
  • In sporadic cases, mandible is the most common site of involvement presenting as jaw tumor or swelling, i.e. is firm, tender without heat or redness.
  • Presence of raised ESR and alkaline phosphatase and anemia mimic infection.
  • In familial form, Tibia > ulna are most frequently involved.
  • Hands and feet are spared.
  • In the long bones, the epiphyses and metaphyses are spared.
  • Increased density of bones is due to massive periosteal new bone.

 

 

Hyperostosis

 

  • Treatment is penicillin G.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Renal osteodystrophy. Renal osteodystrophy refers to bone changes that occur in individuals with chronic kidney disease. It is not synonymous with Caffey's disease.

 

Option C. Osteomyelitis of jaw in children. While Caffey's disease can involve the jaw, it is not caused by bacterial infection, which is a characteristic feature of osteomyelitis.

 

Option D. Chronic osteomyelitis in children. Caffey's disease is not a form of chronic osteomyelitis. Chronic osteomyelitis typically involves persistent infection and inflammation of the bone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Caffey's disease, or Infantile Cortical Hyperostosis (ICH), is characterized by inflammation of the periosteum (the outer layer of bone) leading to cortical bone thickening.
  • Affected infants may experience swelling and tenderness of the affected bones, often the jaw, clavicles, and other long bones.

choices.text: Infants below 6 months

questions.text: Caffey’s disease occurs in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Infants below 6 months

 

Option A.

 

CAFFEY’S DISEASE

 

  • Infantile cortical hyperostosis (Caffey's disease) is a self-limiting disorder characterized by soft tissue swelling, rapid subperiosteal new bone formation, cortical thickening of underlying bones, fever and irritability.
  • Classically, the onset of disease occurs before 6th month of life with resolution by 3 years of age.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Above 5 years. Caffey's disease is not commonly seen above the age of 5 years. It is considered an infantile disorder, and its onset is usually within the first few months of life.

 

Option C. Above 10-20 years. Caffey's disease does not typically occur in individuals above the age of 5, let alone 10-20 years. The condition is specific to infancy.

 

Option D. 20-40 years. Caffey's disease is not observed in individuals aged 20-40 years.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The onset of disease occurs before 6th month of life with resolution by 3 years of age.

questions.text: A bald child with swollen abdomen, hyperosseous bones has:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hypervitaminosis D

 

Option B.

 

HYPERVITAMINOSIS D

 

  • 1,25 (OH) Vit D has an anti-proliferative effect on several cell types, including keratinocytes, breast cancer cells, and prostate cancer cells.
  • Alopecia is seen in Vit D hypervitaminosis and VDRR (Vit D receptor mutation).
  • It exerts a PTH-like effect and so, as in underlying rickets, calcium is withdrawn from bones but metastatic calcification occurs.
  • Chronic hypervitaminosis A: >1 year of age, clinical features are failure to thrive, hepatosplenomegaly, jaundice, alopecia and hemoptysis.
  • Cortical thickening of long and tubular bones, especially in the feet.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Hypervitaminosis C. Hypervitaminosis C, or excess vitamin C, is not associated with hyperosseous bones. Instead, it is commonly associated with scurvy, a condition characterized by weakness, swollen and bleeding gums, and joint pain.

 

Option C. Down's syndrome. Down's syndrome is a genetic condition caused by the presence of an extra copy of chromosome 21. It is not typically associated with hyperosseous bones or a swollen abdomen.

 

Option D. Tuberous Sclerosis. Tuberous sclerosis is a genetic disorder that can affect various organs, including the skin, brain, and kidneys.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A bald child with swollen abdomen, hyperosseous bones has hypervitaminosis D.
  • 1,25 (OH) Vit D has an anti-proliferative effect on several cell types, including keratinocytes, breast cancer cells, and prostate cancer cells.

questions.text:
Hypervitaminosis of which of the following will cause bony abnormalities? 

 

  1. Vit. A
  2. Vit. D
  3. Vit. C
  4. Vit. E
  5. Vit. K
questions.solution:
Ans D) Only 1 & 2

 

Option D.

 

HYPERVITAMINOSIS

 

  • 1,25 (OH) Vit D has an antiproliferative effect on several cell types, including keratinocytes, breast cancer cells, and prostate cancer cells.
  • Alopecia is seen in Vit D hypervitaminosis and VDRR (Vit D receptor mutation).
  • It exerts a PTH-like effect and so, as in underlying rickets, calcium is withdrawn from bones but metastatic calcification occurs.
  • Chronic hypervitaminosis A: >1 year of age, clinical features are failure to thrive, hepatosplenomegaly, jaundice, alopecia and hemoptysis.
  • Cortical thickening of long and tubular bones, especially in the feet.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Excessive vitamin A intake can lead to a condition known as hypervitaminosis A.
  • While it can cause various symptoms, such as nausea, headache, and dizziness, bony abnormalities are not a prominent feature.
  • Hypervitaminosis D can lead to an increased absorption of calcium from the intestines, resulting in hypercalcemia.
  • Prolonged hypercalcemia can cause bony abnormalities, such as hyperostosis and calcification of soft tissues.

questions.text: Osteosclerosis is a feature of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Paget's disease

 

Option C.

 

PATHOPHYSIOLOGY OF PAGET’S DISEASE

 

  • Increased bone resorption accompanied by accelerated bone formation is characteristic feature.
  • Initial osteolytic phase involves prominent bone resorption and marked hypervascularization (Radiologically seen as advancing lytic wedge or blade of grass lesion).
  • 2nd phase of active bone formation and resorption replaces normal lamellar bone with structurally weak woven bone that bend, bow and fracture easily.
  • In 3rd sclerotic (burnt out) phase, bone resorption declines progressively and leads to hard, dense, less vascular pagetic or mosaic bone.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Rickets. Rickets is a condition characterized by soft and weakened bones in children due to a deficiency of vitamin D, calcium, or phosphate. Osteosclerosis is not a feature of rickets; instead, rickets is associated with decreased bone density.

 

Option B. Hyperthyroidism. Hyperparathyroidism is a condition where the parathyroid glands produce excessive parathyroid hormone (PTH), leading to increased levels of calcium in the blood. While hyperparathyroidism can cause bone resorption and result in weakened bones, osteosclerosis is not a prominent feature.

 

Option D. Osteogenesis imperfect. Osteogenesis imperfecta is a genetic disorder characterized by brittle bones and a tendency to fracture easily. Osteosclerosis is not a typical feature of osteogenesis imperfect

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Paget's disease of bone is a chronic disorder characterized by abnormal bone remodeling.
  • Osteosclerosis is a feature of Paget's disease, along with other changes such as bone enlargement, deformities, and increased risk of fractures.

questions.text: Paget’s disease commonly develops in which age group?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 7th decade
