Option D.

 

PAGET’S DISEASE

 

  • People older than 50 are most likely to develop the disease.
  • Men are more commonly affected than are women.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. 1st decade. Paget's disease is extremely rare in the 1st decade of life. The condition is more commonly seen in older individuals, and its prevalence increases with age.

 

Option B. 3rd decade. Paget's disease is still uncommon in the 3rd decade. Most cases are diagnosed in individuals who are older than 40 years.

 

Option C. 5th decade. Paget's disease is more commonly diagnosed in the 5th decade of life. Individuals in their 50s are more likely to exhibit symptoms and signs of Paget's disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Paget’s disease commonly develops in 7th decade.
  • It affects >50years of age.

questions.text: Blades of grass lesion is found in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Paget's disease

 

Option A.

 

PAGET’S DISEASE

 

  • Initial osteolytic phase involves prominent bone resorption and marked hypervascularization.
  • Radiologically, this is seen as advancing lytic wedge or blade of grass lesion.
  • It refers to the lucent leading edge in a long bone seen in Paget disease of bone.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Thalassemia. Thalassemia is a genetic blood disorder and is not typically associated with the "blades of grass" lesion in bone.

 

Option C. Osteoporosis. Osteoporosis is characterized by reduced bone density and an increased risk of fractures, but it does not present with the "blades of grass" lesion.

 

Option D. Carcinoma prostate. Prostate cancer can metastasize to the bones, causing lytic lesions, but the "blades of grass" appearance is not a typical radiological finding associated with prostate cancer metastasis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Blades of grass lesion is found in Paget’s Disease.
  • Long bone X-ray shows deformity, enlargement or expansion of bone with cortical thickening coarsening of trabecular markings with sclerotic changes.

questions.text: Picture frame vertebra is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Paget’s disease

 

Option A.

 

PAGET’S DISEASE

 

  • Vertebral cortical thickening at superior and inferior end plates creates a picture frame vertebrae and diffuse sclerosis causing ivory vertebrae.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Osteopetrosis. Osteopetrosis, also known as marble bone disease or Albers-Schönberg disease, is a group of rare genetic disorders characterized by impaired bone resorption, leading to increased bone density. Radiographically, it presents with “bone within a bone” pattern within the pelvis and long bones and vertebrae, as well as the characteristic “sandwich vertebrae” appearance in the spine.

 

 

Option C. Osteoporosis. X-ray of osteoporossis spine shows codfish vertebra.

 

 

Option D. Ankylosing spondylitis. Ankylosing spondylitis is a type of inflammatory arthritis primarily affecting the spine. Diffuse syndesmophytic ankylosis give a "bamboo spine" appearance.Linear ossification along the central spine representing interspinous ligament ossification can give a "dagger spine" appearance on frontal radiographs.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Picture frame vertebra is seen in Paget’s disease.

questions.text: Disproportionate increase in Alkaline phosphatase levels are seen in which of the following condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Paget’s disease

 

Option C.

 

DIAGNOSIS OF PAGET’S DISEASE

 

  1. Serum calcium and phosphate levels are usually normal.
  2. Increased marker of bone formation (e.g. S. alkaline phosphatase and S. osteocalcin) (ALP levels are used for monitoring Paget’s).
  3. Increased markers of bone resorption – Serum and urinary deoxypyridinoline, N-telopeptide and C-telopeptide:
  • Urinary hydroxyproline
  • Urinary deoxypyridinoline (24 Hours assessment) is most valuable.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Osteoporosis. Alkaline Phosphatase is the marker of bone formation. It is normal in Osteoporosis.

 

Option B. Multiple myeloma. All parameters of Calcium metabolism are raised in Multiple Myeloma except alkaline phosphatase levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Disproportionate increase in Alkaline phosphatase levels are seen in Paget’s disease.

choices.text: Fibrous cortical defect

questions.text: Paget’s disease after 10 years develops into:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Osteosarcoma

 

Option A.

 

COMPLICATIONS OF PAGET’S DISEASE

 

  • < 1% cases of paget’s disease develops into osteosarcoma after years and has poorest prognosis.
  • Other malignancies arising but with lesser frequency are benign GCT or chondrosarcoma.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Fibrous cortical defect. Fibrous cortical defect is a benign bone lesion that is not typically associated with Paget's disease progression. These defects are usually small, non-cancerous areas of bone.

 

Option C. Osteoid osteoma. Osteoid osteoma is a benign bone tumor characterized by the formation of osteoid tissue. It is not a typical progression of Paget's disease. These tumors are usually small and can cause localized pain.

 

Option D. Ankylosing Spondylitis. Ankylosing spondylitis is a separate inflammatory arthritis condition primarily affecting the spine. It is not a typical progression of Paget's disease.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • Paget’s disease after 10 years develops into osteosarcoma in < 1% cases and has poorest prognosis.
  • Other malignancies are benign GCT or chondrosarcoma.

questions.text: Pain in Paget’s disease is relieved best by:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Calcitonin

 

Option D.

 

TREATMENT OF PAGET’S DISEASE

 

  • Bisphosphonates are drug of choice and calcitonin is used to relieve pain.
  • Surgery is done for pathological fractures.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Simple analgesics. Simple analgesics, such as nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) like ibuprofen, may provide relief from mild to moderate pain associated with Paget's disease. They can help reduce inflammation and alleviate discomfort.

 

Option B. Narcotic analgesics. Narcotic analgesics, or opioids, may be considered for more severe pain that is not adequately controlled by simple analgesics.

 

Option C. Radiations. Radiation therapy may be considered in cases where localized pain is not responsive to medications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Bisphosphonates are drug of choice and calcitonin is used to relieve pain.

choices.text: All of the above

questions.text: Hooked vertebrae seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Option D.

 

HOOKED VERTEBRAE

 

  • Bullet-shaped vertebra refers to the anterior beaking of the vertebral body
  • It is seen in the following conditions:
    • Mucopolysaccharidosis (Morquio disease, Hurler disease)
    • Achondroplasia
    • Congenital hypothyroidism
    • Progressive pseudorheumatoid dysplasia
    • Wilson disease

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Achondroplasis. Achondroplasia is a genetic disorder that primarily affects bone growth, leading to dwarfism. Hooked vertebrae is a feature of achondroplasia.

 

Option B. Osteogenesis Imperfecta. Osteogenesis imperfecta (OI) is a genetic disorder characterized by brittle bones that are prone to fractures. Hooked vertebrae is a feature of Osteogenesis Imperfecta.

 

Option C. Congential Hypothyroidism. Congenital hypothyroidism refers to an underactive thyroid gland present from birth. It can have effects on bone development and growth.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • Hooked vertebra can be seen in Achondrplasis, Ostegenesis Imperfecta and Congential hypothyroidism.

choices.text: Due to gene mutation
Shortening of limbs present

questions.text: The following is false about Achondroplasia:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mental retardation

 

Option B.

 

ACHONDROPLASIA

 

  • Inherited as autosomal dominant trait; however, because few achondroplastic people have children, 80–90% of cases are sporadic as a result of spontaneous point mutation in the gene coding for fibroblast growth factor receptor 3 (FGFR-3), which apparently play role in endochondral cartilage growth to regulate linear growth.
  • Glycine to arginine substitution (point mutation) in FGFR-3 gene on chromosome 4p is most mutable single nucleotide in human genome.
  • Paternal age >36 year is linked with new mutation.
  • Endochondral ossification responsible for longitudinal growth is abnormal resulting in short bones.
  • Intramembranous ossification are undisturbed causing normal clavicles and skull vault.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Disproportionate dwarfism
    • Disproportionate rhizomelic micromelia, i.e. short stature – most severe in proximal limbs.
    • Trunk height normal, but arm span and standing height are diminished.
    • Ultimate height is about 4 feet 4 inches (131 cm) for males and 4 feet 1 inch (124 cm) for females.
    • Skull is large with prominent forehead (frontal bossing), saddle-shaped nose (flat and depressed nasal bridge), small maxilla, prominent mandibles and normal dentition.
    • Usually have normal intelligence
    • Hands are short and broad.
    • The middle finger is shorter than usual resulting in all of the digits being of equal length (Starfish hand).
    • There is separation between middle and ring fingers, described as trident hand or main en trident.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Autosomal dominant. This statement is true. Achondroplasia is usually inherited in an autosomal dominant manner, meaning that a person with achondroplasia has a 50% chance of passing the condition on to their offspring.

 

Option C. Due to gene mutation. This statement is true. Achondroplasia is caused by a mutation in the FGFR3 gene, which leads to abnormal bone growth.

 

Option D. Shortening of limbs present. This statement is true. One of the hallmark features of achondroplasia is short stature, particularly in the limbs. The trunk is usually of normal length, while the arms and legs are shorter than average.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • This given statement is false. Mental retardation is not a characteristic feature of achondroplasia. Individuals with achondroplasia typically have normal intelligence.

questions.text: “Trident hand” is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Achondroplasia

 

Option A.

 

TRIDENT HAND

 

  • A hand in which the fingers are of nearly equal length and deflected at the first interphalangeal joint, to give a fork-like shape consisting of separation of the first and second as well as the third and fourth digits.
  • It is seen in achondroplasia.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Mucopolysaccharidosis. Mucopolysaccharidoses are a group of metabolic disorders characterized by the accumulation of glycosaminoglycans. This condition involves Carpal tunnel syndrome which restricts the hand mobility and function.

 

Option C. Diaphyseal aclasis. Hereditary multiple exostoses/osteochondromas, also known as diaphyseal aclasis, osteochondromatosis, or simply multiple osteochondromas, is an autosomal dominant condition, characterized by the development of multiple osteochondromas. This involves formation of lesions in the bones. There is broadening of the shaft of the end of long bones.

 

Option D. Cleidocranial Dysostosis. Cleidocranial dysostosis is a genetic disorder that affects the development of bones, particularly the skull and collar bones. This involves pes planus, genu valgum, scoliosis and osteoporosis.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • Trident Hand is a characteristic finding in some genetic or developmental disorders like Achondroplasia where there is a separation between the middle and ring fingers.

questions.text: Absent lateral 1/3rd of clavicle is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cleidocranial dysostosis

 

Option D.

 

CLEIDOCRANIAL DYOSTOSIS

 

  • It is an autosomal dominant (AD) disorder where bones formed by intramembranous ossification are abnormal (primarily clavicles, cranium and pelvis).
  • Clavicles maybe underdeveloped or absent.
  • The most common defect is loss of lateral 1/3rd > loss of middle third of clavicle.
  • Due to absence of clavicle shoulders look droopy and chest appears narrow.
  • When it is bilateral clavicle hypoplasia, child can touch the shoulders together in front of the chest.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Hyperparathyroidism. Hyperparathyroidism is characterized by overactivity of the parathyroid glands, leading to increased levels of parathyroid hormone (PTH) and elevated calcium levels. It is not typically associated with absent lateral 1/3rd of the clavicle.

 

Option B. Turner’s syndrome. Turner's syndrome is a genetic condition that affects females and is characterized by the absence or underdevelopment of the X chromosome. In some cases, there can be skeletal abnormalities, but the absent lateral 1/3rd of the clavicle is not a classic feature.

 

Option C. Fibrous dysplasia. Fibrous dysplasia is a bone disorder where normal bone is replaced with fibrous tissue. It is not typically associated with absent lateral 1/3rd of the clavicle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Absent lateral 1/3rd of clavicle is seen in Cleidocranial dysostosis.
  • Cleidocranial dysostosis is a genetic disorder that affects the development of bones, particularly the skull and collarbones (clavicles).
  • In individuals with cleidocranial dysostosis, the clavicles may be underdeveloped or absent, contributing to the characteristic appearance.

choices.text: Marble bone disease is another name of it
Hyperlaxity of ligaments with hypermobile joints
Cranial nerve compression may occur
Treatment involves bone marrow transplantation

questions.text: Osteogenesis imperfecta, true is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hyperlaxity of ligaments with hypermobile joints

 

Option B.

 

OSTEOGENESIS IMPERFECTA

 

  • Osteogenesis Imperfecta/Brittle Bone Disease is a genetic disorder of connective tissue determined by quantitative qualitative defect in type I collagen formation.
  • So there is reduction in the total amount of type I collagen.
  • It is inherited from a parent in autosomal dominant (AD) fashion.
  • Clinical features:
    • The defining clinical features are osteopenia causing repeated propensity to fracture, often without much pain or swelling.
    • Fractures heal at a normal rate.
    • According to the severity of disease, fractures may occur in uterus, at birth, or after birth prior to or after walking age.
    • Lower limb fractures are more common than upper limb.
    • Femur is commonly fractured followed by tibia.
    • Frequency of fractures decline after adolescence or puberty, although it may rise again in postmenopausal women.
    • Hyperlaxity of ligaments results in joint hypermobility.
    • Deafness in adolescence or adulthood maybe of the conductive type due to otosclerosis or of nerve type, caused by pressure on the auditory nerve as it emerges from the skull.
  • Treatment:
    • Bisphosphonates: One of the few indications of bisphosphonates growing age.
    • Ideal treatment: replace COLIA1 or COLIA2 gene.


Explanation:

 

Option A. Marble bone disease is another name of it. Marble bone disease is a term more commonly associated with osteopetrosis, which is a different genetic disorder characterized by increased bone density. Osteogenesis imperfecta is often referred to as "brittle bone disease."

 

Option C. Cranial nerve compression may occur. This statement is not correct as in osteogenesis imperfecta, cranial nerve compression may not occur. The auditory nerve can be compressed, leading to conductive or nerve type deafness.

 

Option D. Treatment involves bone marrow transplantation. Treatment for osteogenesis imperfect is Bisphosphonates in growing age, and replacement of COLIA1 or COLIA2 gene.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Osteogenesis imperfecta is also called as brittle bones disease.
  • Hyperlaxity of ligaments with hypermobile joints is common in this disease.
  • Auditory nerve compression may occur, leading to deafness.
  • Treatment involves use of bisphosphonates.

questions.text: Which of the below is a feature of osteogenesis imperfecta?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Blue sclera

 

Option A.

 

OCULAR FEATURES OF OSTEOGENESIS IMPERFECTA

 

  • “Blue or gray sclerae”, is because of uveal pigment showing through thin collagen layer.
  • Saturn’s ring is white sclera immediately surrounding the cornea.
  • Arcus juvenilis or embryotoxon, is opacity in periphery of cornea.
  • Hyperopia and retinal detachment may occur.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Cataract. Cataracts, or clouding of the lens of the eye, are not typically associated with osteogenesis imperfecta.

 

Option C. Anterior uveitis. Anterior uveitis, or inflammation of the front part of the uvea (the middle layer of the eye), is not a characteristic feature of osteogenesis imperfecta.

 

Option D. Retinal detachment. Retinal detachment is not a typical feature of osteogenesis imperfecta. Osteogenesis imperfecta primarily affects the bones and is not directly associated with eye conditions like retinal detachment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Blue sclera is a characteristic feature of osteogenesis imperfecta.
  • The connective tissue in the sclera (the white part of the eye) is thinner and less opaque, allowing the underlying choroid to show through, giving the appearance of a blue or gray tint.

questions.text: Osteogenesis imperfecta has abnormality in which type of collagen?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Collagen 1

 

Option D.

 

OSTEOGENESIS IMPERFECTA

 

  • Osteogenesis Imperfecta/Brittle Bone Disease is a genetic disorder of connective tissue determined by quantitative qualitative defect in type I collagen formation.
  • So, there is alteration in the structural integrity, or a reduction in the total amount of type I collagen, one of the major components of fibrillar connective tissue in skin, ligaments, bones, sclera, and teeth.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Collagen 3. Collagen type III is a fibrillar collagen found in tissues such as skin, lungs, and blood vessels. It is involved in providing structural support and integrity to these tissues.

 

Option B. Collagen 2. Collagen type II is a fibrillar collagen that is a major component of cartilage.

It provides structural support and tensile strength to cartilage, which is essential for its function in joints.

 

Option C. Collagen 4. Collagen type IV is a non-fibrillar collagen found in basement membranes, a specialized form of extracellular matrix. It plays a crucial role in maintaining the integrity and structure of basement membranes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Osteogenesis imperfecta has abnormality in type 1 collagen.
  • It is a genetic disorder of connective tissue determined by quantitative qualitative defect in type I collagen formation.
  • So, there is alteration in the structural integrity, or a reduction in the total amount of type I collagen, one of the major components of fibrillar connective tissue in skin, ligaments, bones, sclera, and teeth.

questions.text: A child presented with hip pain. What is the diagnosis based on the given radiograph?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Osteogenesis imperfect

 

Option A.

 

OSTEOGENESIS IMPERFECTA

 

  • Clinical features:
    • The defining clinical features are osteopenia causing repeated propensity to fracture, generally after minor trauma and often without much pain or swelling.
    • Fractures heal at a normal rate.
    • Lower limb fractures are more common than upper limb.
    • Femur is commonest bone fractured followed by tibia.
    • Hyperlaxity of ligaments, with resultant hypermobility of joint is common.
    • Rarely recurrent dislocation of patella, radial head and hip joint dislocation and DDH can occur.
  • Radiological Features:
    • Wormian bones are detached portions of primary ossification centers of adjacent membrane bones. These are seen in skull X-ray.
    • These are arranged in mosaic pattern.
    • Ring-shaped epiphysis is seen.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Osteoporosis. Osteoporosis is a condition characterized by low bone density, which leads to an increased risk of fractures. It is more common in older adults, particularly postmenopausal women, but can occur in children as well. It is commonly asymptomatic until a fracture occurs.  

 

Option C. Osteopetrosis. Osteopetrosis is a rare genetic disorder characterized by increased bone density due to impaired bone resorption by osteoclasts. It can cause bone pain, fractures, and skeletal abnormalities.

 

Option D. Osteopoikilocytosis. Osteopoikilocytosis is a term usually associated with a rare genetic disorder affecting red blood cells, not bones. It involves abnormalities in the shape of red blood cells (poikilocytes) and is not directly related to hip pain or bone disorders.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A child presented with hip pain with the given radiograph, has Osteogenesis imperfecta.
  • Osteogenesis imperfecta is a genetic disorder characterized by brittle bones that are prone to fractures.
  • It can lead to skeletal deformities and is associated with mutations in the genes responsible for collagen type 1 synthesis.

choices.text: Abnormal Pro-alpha chain of collagen molecule

questions.text: Prenatal determination of osteogenesis imperfecta is done by:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Abnormal Pro-alpha chain of collagen molecule

 

Option C.

 

OSTEOGENESIS IMPERFECTA

 

  • A reliable diagnosis of the perinatal osteogenesis imperfecta can be made by ultrasound examination during the second trimester, by identification of fractures of the long bones.
  • The compression of the fetal head by the ultrasound probe and the low echogeneity of the cranium, should raise the suspicion of skeletal dysplasia, but is not diagnostic for osteogenesis imperfecta.
  • In families with a previously affected fetus, prenatal diagnosis by first trimester transvaginal ultrasound investigation or chorionic villus sampling should be discussed.
  • Prenatally, abnormality of pro-alpha chain of collagen molecules is suggestive of osteogenesis imperfecta in the fetus by polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis.

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Alkaline phosphatase. Acid phosphatase is an enzyme found in various tissues, including bone. However, it is not specifically used for prenatal determination of osteogenesis imperfecta. Acid phosphatase assays are more commonly associated with certain bone disorders and conditions affecting the prostate.

 

Option B. Alkaline Phosphatase. Alkaline phosphatase is an enzyme found in various tissues, including the bones and liver. It plays a role in bone mineralization. While elevated levels of alkaline phosphatase can be associated with certain bone disorders, it is not a direct method for prenatal determination of osteogenesis imperfecta.

 

Option D. FGF3 mutation. Fibroblast Growth Factor 3 (FGF3) is not directly associated with osteogenesis imperfecta.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Osteogenesis imperfecta is primarily caused by mutations in the genes that encode the pro-alpha chains of collagen type I.
  • The abnormal pro-alpha chains result in defective collagen synthesis, leading to brittle bones.

questions.text: All are features of osteogenesis imperfecta except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cataract

 

Option C.

 

CLINICAL FEATURES OSTEOGENESIS IMPERFECTA

 

  • The defining clinical features are osteopenia causing repeated propensity to fracture.
  • Lower limb fractures are more common than upper limb.
  • Femur is commonest bone fractured followed by tibia.
  • Hyperlaxity of ligaments, with resultant hypermobility of joint
  • Rarely recurrent dislocation of patella, radial head and hip joint dislocation and DDH can occur.
  • “Blue or gray sclerae” because of uveal pigment showing through thin collagen layer.
  • Saturn’s ring is white sclera surrounding the cornea.
  • Arcus juvenilis or embryotoxon – opacity in periphery of cornea.
  • Hyperopia and retinal detachment may occur.
  • Deafness of the conductive type due to otosclerosis or of nerve type, caused by pressure on the auditory nerve as it emerges from the skull.
  • The enamel is normal.
  • Both deciduous and permanent teeth are involved – break easily and prone to carries.
  • Yellowish brown or bluish gray discoloration of teeth.
  • The lower incisors more severely affected.
  • Skin is thin and translucent.
  • Subcutaneous hemorrhages may occur.
  • Muscles are hypotonic due to multiple fractures and deformities.
  • Hernias may occur.
  • Excessive sweating, heat intolerance due to hypermetabolic state.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Blue Sclera. Blue sclera is a distinctive feature in individuals with osteogenesis imperfecta. It results from the translucency of the connective tissues in the eye, allowing the underlying choroidal veins to be visible through the thin sclera.

 

Option B. Multiple Fractures. Multiple fractures are a hallmark of osteogenesis imperfecta. Due to the genetic mutations affecting collagen type I synthesis, individuals with OI have bones that are brittle and prone to fractures, even with minimal trauma.

 

Option D. Hearing loss. Conductive and sensorineural hearing loss can occur in individuals with osteogenesis imperfecta. The hearing loss is often related to abnormalities in the middle ear bones (ossicles) or inner ear structures, which can be affected by the same collagen deficiencies responsible for bone fragility.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Multiple fractures, deafness (hearing loss) due to otosclerosis and blue sclera is seen.
  • Cataract is not a feature.

questions.text: Wormian bones are seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Osteogenesis imperfect

 

Option A.

 

WORMIAN BONES

 

  • Wormian bones are detached portions of primary ossification centers of adjacent membrane bones.
  • These are seen in skull X-ray.
  • To be significant, it should be more than 10 in number, measure at least 6 mm × 4 mm, and be arranged in general mosaic pattern.
  • Wormian bones are present in osteogenesis imperfecta, other bone dysplasias such as cleidocranial dysplasia, congenital hypothyroidism, and some trisomies.
  • Ring-shaped epiphysis is seen.

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Scheuermann’s disease. Scheuermann's disease, also known as Scheuermann's kyphosis, is a skeletal disorder that typically affects the thoracic spine, causing abnormal curvature (kyphosis). It is characterized by wedging of the vertebral bodies and can result in a rounded or hunched back. Wormian bones are not a characteristic feature of Scheuermann's disease.

 

Option C. Paget’s disease. Paget's disease of bone is a chronic condition that results in the abnormal remodeling of bone. It can lead to enlarged and deformed bones, but the presence of Wormian bones is not a typical feature of Paget's disease.

 

Option D. Osteosarcoma. Osteoclastoma, also known as giant cell tumor of bone, is a type of benign tumor that primarily affects the epiphyses (ends) of long bones. While osteoclastomas can cause bone destruction and abnormalities, the presence of Wormian bones is not a characteristic finding associated with this tumor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Wormian bones are seen in Osteogenesis imperfecta, a genetic disorder characterized by brittle bones.
  • The presence of Wormian bones is in the skull.

choices.text: Low levels of serum calcium
Raised levels of alkaline phosphatase
Low levels of PTH
Low levels of serum phosphate

questions.text: What is false about Osteopetrosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Low levels of PTH

 

Option C.

 

OSTEOPETROSIS

 

  • It is a diaphyseal dysplasia characterized by failure of bone resorption due to functional deficiency of osteoclast.
  • The bone contains increased number of osteoclasts but these do not resorb bone as evidenced by absence of ruffled borders and clear zones and are unable to respond to PTH.
  • Due to functional deficiency of osteoclasts, calcified chondroid (cartilage) and primitive woven bone persists down into metaphysis and diaphysis leading to osteosclerosis and increased brittleness of bones (marble bone disease).
  • Laboratory parameters:
  • Serum calcium low
  • Serum PTH high
  • Serum phosphate low
  • Serum ALP high

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Low levels of serum calcium. In osteopetrosis, the defective bone resorption can lead to impaired calcium release from bones into the bloodstream.

 

Option B. Raised levels of alkaline phosphastase. Alkaline phosphatase is often elevated in osteopetrosis due to increased bone turnover and remodelling.

 

Option C. Low levels of serum phosphate. Osteopetrosis is not typically associated with low levels of serum phosphate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The statement which is false about osteopetrosis is low levels of parathyroid hormones.
  • Laboratory parameters are serum calcium low, serum PTH high, serum phosphate low and serum ALP high.

questions.text: Albers Schonberg disease is also known as:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Osteopetrosis

 

Option B.

 

OSTEOPETROSIS

 

  • Also known as marble bone disease or Albers Schonberg disease, osteopetrosis is diaphyseal dysplasia characterized by failure of the bone resorption due to functional deficiency of osteoclast, leading to osteosclerosis and increased brittleness of the bones.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Osteoporosis. Osteoporosis is also known as silent disease because it is asymptomatic until a bone is fractured.

 

Option C. Osteogenesis imperfecta. It is also known as brittle bone disease because the bones are more prone to fracture at any time of the life, in utero, during birth, or after birth.

 

Option D. Paget’s disease. It is also known as osteitis deformans because it involves formation of bones which are abnormally large and weak, more prone to break easily.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Albers Schonberg disease is another name for osteopetrosis or marble bone disease.

choices.text: Delayed fracture healing
Cranial nerve compression
Osteomyelitis of mandible

questions.text: Regarding osteopetrosis, all the following statements are true except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Delayed fracture healing

 

Option B.

 

CLINICAL FEATURES OF OSTEOPETROSIS

 

  • Autosomal dominant or benign type is asymptomatic in adult patients. It may present with mild anemia, pathological fractures premature osteoarthritis, and rarely osteomyelitis of mandible.
  • Autosomal recessive or malignant (congenital) osteopetrosis clinically presents at birth or in early infancy because of obliteration of marrow cavity by bony overgrowth resulting in inability of bone marrow to participate in hematopoiesis. Pancytopenia develops resulting in abnormal bleeding, easy bruising, progressive anemia, and failure to thrive.
  • Severe infections esp. Mandible
  • Extramedullary hematopoiesis causing hepatosplenomegaly.
  • Cranial nerve palsies due to bony overgrowth of cranial foramen – 2nd, 7th and 8th—blindness and deafness
  • Fragile brittle bones
  • Pathological fractures.
  • Fractures usually heal at slower rates in osteopetrosis but few studies have shown fracture healing is normal.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Pancytopenia. Osteopetrosis can lead to pancytopenia, which is a condition characterized by a reduction in the number of red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets. The increased bone density in osteopetrosis can cause bone marrow crowding, leading to reduced hematopoiesis. Bone encroachment on marrow results in bone marrow failure with resultant pancytopenia.

 

Option C. Cranial nerve compression. The increased bone density in osteopetrosis can cause narrowing of the cranial foramina, leading to compression of cranial nerves. This compression can result in various neurological symptoms, including vision and hearing impairment.

 

Option D. Osteomyelitis in Mandible. Osteopetrosis can predispose individuals to osteomyelitis, especially in the mandible. Osteomyelitis of the mandible is common due to pancytopenia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cranial nerve compression due to bone encroachment on foramina may occur.
  • Osteomyelitis of the mandible is common due to pancytopenia.
  • Bone encroachment on marrow results in bone marrow failure with resultant pancytopenia.
  • Fractures usually heal at slower rates in osteopetrosis but few studies have shown fracture healing is normal.
  • Thus, all 4 options are correct. In case we have to choose one, it will be delayed healing of fracture as there is no debate about other features.

choices.text: Myositis ossificans progressiva

questions.text: A 3-year-old male presented with progressive anemia, hepatosplenomegaly and osteomyelitis of jaw with pathological fracture. X-ray shows chalky white deposits on bone. Probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Osteopetrosis

 

Option A.

 

OSTEOPETROSIS

 

  • The autosomal recessive or malignant type of osteopetrosis is present congenitally.
  • It clinically presents at birth or in early infancy due to obliterated marrow cavity by bony overgrowth.
  • This results in an inability of the bone marrow to participate in hematopoiesis.
  • Pancytopenia develops and results in abnormal bleeding, easy bruising, progressive anemia, and failure to thrive.
  • Severe infections or osteomyelitis of mandible may also occur.
  • Radiological hallmark is increased radiopacity of bones, giving a chalky-white appearance because the intramedullary canal is filled with bone.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Osteopoikilocytosis. Osteopoikilocytosis is not a term commonly associated with a specific bone disorder. It is more commonly used in the context of certain red blood cell abnormalities. It is not a feature of osteopetrosis.

 

Option C. Alkaptonuria. Alkaptonuria is a metabolic disorder characterized by the accumulation of homogentisic acid, leading to dark pigmentation in urine and connective tissues. This is not seen in osteopetrosis.

 

Option D. Myositis ossificans progressiva. Myositis ossificans progressiva, also known as fibrodysplasia ossificans progressiva (FOP), is a rare genetic disorder where soft tissues progressively turn into bone. This is also not a feature of osteopetrosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Osteopetrosis is a genetic disorder characterized by increased bone density due to defective bone resorption by osteoclasts.
  • Common features include brittle bones, increased fracture susceptibility, pancytopenia due to bone marrow crowding, and, in some cases, cranial nerve compression.
  • Pancytopenia may lead to progressive anemia, hepatosplenomegaly and mandibular infections.
  • X-ray with chalky white deposits on bone can be seen in osteopetrosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common muscle to be congenitally absent?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pectoralis major

 

Option A.

 

CONGENITAL ABSENCE OF PECTORALIS MUSCLES

 

  • Congenital variations occur more frequently in the pectoralis than in any other of the skeletal muscles.
  • Pectoralis major and minor are the most common congenitally absent muscles.
  • Agenesis is often partial and maybe part of a syndrome associated with other anomalies—Poland syndrome.
  • Patients typically present with a flattened chest wall, with hypoplastic ribs, an elevated nipple and may present with unilateral hyper radiolucency of the lung on a roentgenogram.
  • Diagnosis is often established on ultrasound and is mainly based on the absence of a muscle belly or tendon.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Semimembranosus. The semimembranosus is one of the hamstring muscles located in the posterior thigh. Congenital absence of the semimembranosus is relatively uncommon, and specific conditions associated with the absence of this muscle are less frequently reported.

 

Option C. Teres Minor. The teres minor is a small muscle in the rotator cuff of the shoulder. Congenital absence of the teres minor is rare and might be associated with other shoulder or rotator cuff abnormalities.

 

Option D. Gluteus maximus. The gluteus maximus is the largest muscle in the buttocks and is involved in hip extension. Congenital absence of the gluteus maximus is extremely rare, and there are limited reports of such cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • While congenital absence of certain muscles is associated with specific conditions (e.g., Poland syndrome for pectoralis major), the absence of muscles like semimembranosus, teres minor, or gluteus maximus is uncommon and may be part of rare congenital anomalies.
  • The most common muscle to be congenitally absent among the options provided is the pectoralis major.
